radha is eating a mango. continue.. activity 1 read these sentences and decide whether they pertain to actions of past, present or future. fill the answer table provided. 1. he was sad to hear the news. 2. prem worked hard to make it through. 3. rateesh will help us in all possible ways. 4. he is sad to hear the news. 5. radha was eating a mango. 6. forward back joseph is writing a book on apiculture. 7. rateesh helps us in all possible ways. 8. prem works hard to make it through. 9. radha will eat a mango. 10. joseph was writing a book on apiculture. 11. joseph will write a book on apiculture. 12. back rateesh helped us in all possible ways. 13. he will be sad to hear the news. 14. prem will work hard to make it through. 15. forward back present (happens now) past (already happened) future (yet to happen) type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here

what was your basis of categorizing the sentences as past, present and future? in all languages, time is divided into 3 frames- now- refers to the current time (present tense) past- refers to the time before now (past tense) future- refers to the time after now (future tense) continue.. in this module, we will understand- what tenses are regular verbs irregular verbs when and how to use the past, present and future tenses correct usage of verb forms in different tenses forward back as you can observe in the table above, to denote different tense forms, verb forms need to be changed. past present future simple i studied i study i will study continuous i was studying i am studying i will be studying perfect i had studied i have studied i will have studied depending on the time of action, verbs need to be changed in various forms such as their past, present participle and past participle. helping verbs like ‘will, have, be’ are also used for denoting different tenses. therefore, let us first understand regular and irregular verbs and how their forms are changed. back

regular and irregular verbs regular verbs verbs that form their past and past participle forms by adding -d or -ed to their base forms are regular verbs. when you want to change the base form of a regular verb to its past form, suffix –d to those verbs that end with a vowel and –ed to those ending with a consonant. for example, please explain your statement. he explained his statement. type this letter for me. she typed the letter for me. she can bake delicious pastries. she baked delicious pastries.

list of some regular verbs and their forms simple past past participle worry worried worried attack attacked attacked bake baked baked drag dragged dragged earn earned earned introduce introduced introduced harass harassed harassed hate hated hated jump jumped jumped explain explained explained fry fried fried cycle cycled cycled simple past past participle damage damaged damaged kiss kissed kissed love loved loved marry married married murder murdered murdered need needed needed open opened opened paint painted painted push pushed pushed list of some regular verbs and their forms (contd.) question questioned questioned laugh laughed laughed simple past past participle rub rubbed rubbed scold scolded scolded list of some regular verbs and their forms (contd.) type typed typed

examples case in the above table, did you notice that not all of the forms follow the simple addition of -d or -ed. click examples to read the rules for special cases. the fish was fried till it turned golden brown. (fry) rule examples when a verb ends with -y, preceded by a consonant, we drop the -y and add -ied. she is married to a famous industrialist. (marry) when the verb ends with -y, preceded by a vowel, you should only add -ed without dropping -y. geeta stayed with me for a couple of weeks. (stay) when a verb ends with a consonant that is preceded by a vowel, the consonant is repeated in the past form. (-ed is suffixed) i dragged my cycle which had a flat tyre. (drag) she admitted that she had stolen the money. (admit)

irregular verbs the difference between a regular and an irregular verb is in the way how their past and past participle forms are formed. the simple past and past participle forms of irregular verbs could take various forms, with no regularity in their pattern. the most common errors that we make with irregular verbs are to add -d or -ed to form their past tenses. e.g.: swimmed, teached, etc. irregular verbs do not follow the standard rules of verb forms. therefore there is no other way of avoiding mistakes with irregular verbs than to learn them all. go through as many of them as possible along with their past and participle forms.

irregular verb list simple past past participle begin began begun build built built tell told told steal stole stolen spend spent spent break broke broken come came come sit sat sat sing sang sung dig dug dug choose chose chosen simple past past participle list of some regular verbs and their forms (contd.) eat ate eaten fall fell fallen run ran run ring rang rung feed fed fed hide hid hidden swing swung swung put put put quit quit quit tear tore torn simple past past participle list of some regular verbs and their forms (contd.) read read (pronounce as red) read (pronounce as red) see saw seen slide slid slid feel felt felt grind ground ground

if you have gone through the list of verbs and their forms thoroughly, let us move on to tenses again. you will now find it much easier to align the correct verb forms with the appropriate tenses. past/ present/ future simple perfect perfect continuous continuous

tenses past, present and future present past future radha is eating a mango. radha was eating a mango. radha will eat a mango. he is sad to hear the news. he was sad to hear the news. he will be sad to hear the news. joseph is writing a book on apiculture. joseph was writing a book on apiculture. joseph will write a book on apiculture. rateesh helps us in all possible ways. rateesh helped us in all possible ways. rateesh will help us in all possible ways. prem works hard to make it through. prem worked hard to make it through. prem will work hard to make it through. continue.. check your answers for activity 1 here- the tense charts given in a concise format give you an idea of how to construct sentences correctly to indicate the correct time frame. tenses past, present and future knowledge of tenses is essential for proper sentence formation. the examples given will make the usage and syntax of each tense form clear. back

tense simple present present continuous present perfect present perfect continuous when do i use it? to show an action which happens now or many a times. it also shows your habits, abilities or general facts. to show an action that is happening right now. also shows an action planned for future. to show an action that finished recently, though its time of completion is not mentioned. to show an action which began in the past but is still continuing in the present. how do i use it? verb in its base form and should agree with the subject is/am/are +verb+ing has/have+past participle form of verb has/have been+ verb+ing examples ashwin sleeps in his room. ashwin is sleeping in his room. (it is still happening) ashwin has slept in his room. (the action is completed but its effect still persists) ashwin has been sleeping in his room since last night. (it started in the past and is still continuing) present tense

tense simple past past continuous past perfect past perfect continuous when do i use it? to show that an action happened in the past and is now over. to show an action was taking place at some time in the past but is now over. to show an action got completed before the onset of another action. that an action that was continuing in the past is now over. how do i use it? verb in its past form, compliant with the subject was/were+verb in its (verb+ing) form had+ past participle form of verb had been+verb+ing examples she drank a glass of water. (action completed in the past) she was drinking a glass of water. (the action was in progress in the past) she had drunk a glass of water before going out. (the action got over in the past itself) she had been drinking a glass of water when i called her. (the event was continuing for some time in the past) past tense

tense simple future future continuous future perfect future perfect continuous when do i use it? to show a future action or a prediction. to show an action that shall be happening at some time in the future. to show that an action will happen before a particular time in the future. to show a continuing action which will happen before a specific time in future. how do i use it? will/shall + verb will +be+verb+ing will + have+past participle form of verb will+have+been+ verb+ing examples neeraj will check the document next week. (happening of the event in future) neeraj will be checking the document next week. (the action will be in progress in the future) neeraj will have checked the document by next week. (expected to complete an action in the future, usually before some point of time) next week, neeraj will have been doing this work for 5 months. future tense

the bare brown mountains topped with green trees are a feast for our eyes. we speed up towards the trekking area but soon got drain as our rucksacks, which contains ample provision for the day, is heavy and impeded our progress. at last we dragged ourselves into the base camp that has been arranged for us. the second hurdle that awaited us was that we had to cooked food for ourselves. answer last summer my classmates and i went trekking to a mountainous area close to our city. we were twenty of us including three teachers. the weather was pleasant and we were very excited as most of us were going for a trek for the first time. mussorie, a small hill station on the foothills of lesser himalayas is one of the most picturesque places i’ve ever been to. the scenery around left us dumbstruck! the bare brown mountains topped with green trees were a feast for our eyes. we sped up towards the trekking area but soon got drained as our rucksacks, which contained ample provision for the day, were heavy and impeded our progress. at last we dragged ourselves into the base camp that had been arranged for us. the second hurdle that awaited us was that we had to cook food for ourselves.
subject and predicate start

in a sentence, we essentially include two parts- we identify a person or a thing. (the subject) mention something about the person or thing. (the predicate) for example- the mountain is covered with snow. in this sentence, what we are speaking about is the mountain, which makes it the subject; what is being spoken about the mountain is that it is covered with snow- this is the predicate of the sentence. thus, all sentences consist essentially of two parts- the subject and the predicate. continue.. consider the same example again- (the mountain is covered) with snow. the part of the sentence enclosed in brackets is a complete sentence in itself, with a subject (the mountain) and predicate (is covered). in addition to the subject and predicate, there is a complement which gives you more information. thus, a predicate could be a single word verb or consist of complements which tell us more about what the subject does. back..

identifying subject and predicate many a times, the subject is not as easily identifiable as in the previous examples. here comes the prince. this is the sweetest song i’ve ever heard. in such cases, the subject can be spotted by asking questions 'who' or 'what'. here, the answer to who comes is ‘the prince’, therefore it is the subject. sometimes when a sentence is used for giving a command, such as in an imperative sentence, the subject isn’t quite visible. for e.g.: take your seat. here the hidden but obvious subject is ‘you’. continue.. identifying subject and predicate in a sentence, there could be more than one subject joined by and, or, either, neither…nor. for example- kangaroos and koala bears are marsupials. is your uncle or aunt coming? thus, to identify a subject, try to understand who or what the sentence talks about. this will be clear from the exercises that follow. back..

subject verb agreement "let us make them agree…" start subject verb

having plural subjects with singular verbs or the reverse, results in confusing sentences, which fail to convey your meaning. this becomes particularly important when long phrases separate the subject from the verb. understanding subject-verb agreement helps you create clear sentences that the reader or listener will understand. the simple and only rule to remember in subject-verb agreement is ‘singular verb for singular subject and plural verb for plural subject.’ before learning the rules for subject-verb agreement, let us briefly take up what a subject in a sentence means. continue.. what is a subject? a subject is the ‘head-word’ in a sentence. the subject is the most important word in a sentence. the subject may also be treated as ‘naming word’. that is, the subject may be the names of the persons, places or pronouns. what is a predicate? a predicate is the verb or verbal group in a sentence. the verb is also known as a saying part, it tells the action done by the subject. back.. forward.. he (mohan) writes i am singing cows give milk maria is a hardworking girl subject predicate in the sentences, the number of the subject (singular or plural) matches with the number of verb. there are some definite rules governing the agreement of subjects with verbs which will be taken up here. back.. forward.. he (mohan) (singular) writes (singular) i (singular) am singing (singular) cows (plural) give milk (plural) maria (singular) is a hardworking girl (singular) subject predicate the plurals of verbs are usually their base forms themselves. e.g.: give, make, etc. their singular forms are usually formed by suffixing -s to them. the easiest and usually the most reliable way to identify subjects is to ask and answer the questions ‘who’ and ‘what’. for example, rohan is going to brazil. (who is going?- rohan) it is also important to keep in mind the ‘person’ - 1st, 2nd or 3rd that is being used in the sentence. back..

person - who is being spoken about? 1st person or the self (i, me, we) 2nd person or the person spoken to (you) 3rd person or the person spoken about (he, she, him, her, they, them). knowledge of ‘persons’ is important from subject verb agreement point of view as verbs change form with different persons. as can be seen from the table- continue.. person - who is being spoken about? verbs are always plural with 1st and 2nd persons. they take singular and plural forms with 3rd person depending on whether the subject is singular or plural. e.g. farida wakes up at 5 everyday. (singular) they wake up at 5 everyday. (plural) back..

example 3 example 2 example 1 person - who is being spoken about? click each example to read more. person first (speaker) singular i plural we examples i make, we make i was , we were person second (being spoken to) singular you plural you examples you make , you were person third (being spoken about) singular he, she, it plural they examples hari works here. tanuja likes this place. they want to meet us. it is impossible for us to come there.

the next section contains tables which can be used by you as easy to remember flash cards which will help you solve some tricky exercises later. use these flash cards to get a good grip on sv-agreement.

case 2 case 1 what? click each case to read more. implication verb should also be singular subject singular action add -s or -es to verb (not applicable when subject is i or you) examples my bottle is broken. she reads novels by hemingway. subject plural implication verb should also be plural action drop –s or –es from verb examples these bottles are broken. they read novels by hemingway.

case 10 case 9 what? click each case to read more. implication verb singular with ‘the number’ and plural with ‘a number’ subject is the word ‘number’ action refer case 1 and 2 examples the number of countries which participate in the conference is decreasing. a number of countries participate in the carnival. subject is a collective noun implication verb singular when subject considered as a unit and plural when referred to individually action refer case 1 and 2 examples the furious mob want to break into the minister’s chambers. his family is in lucknow.

answers though women are still being cowed down, it is heartening to see the number of girls thronging schools and colleges and facing the challenges of the world in their professional set ups. they are doing exceedingly well as entrepreneurs, doctors, researchers and technologists. imparting knowledge and serving humanity are the foremost natural abilities and no one can have a more humane touch than a woman, whose love, patience and understanding help to alleviate illiteracy, pain and suffering. in urban society one sees women growing in strength and character but our counterparts in rural areas are also not far behind. they have left their hearths to work and become self dependent. earning their bread and adding to the income of the family so as to lead better lives are of prime importance to them. they are the ones who are providing their children with education and securing their lives. questions continue

continue.. fill in the box with details about yourself. name dob city father's occupation mother's occupation education (school) education (college) area of expertise employer position held experience (years) type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here hello, i am __________________ . i was born on __________________ in __________________. my father works as a __________________ and mother works as a __________________. i studied in __________________ school and graduated from __________________ college. i specialize in __________________ and work with __________________ as a __________________. i have been working here for __________________ . back.. now fill in the information in these sentences. type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here forward.. hello, i am __________________ . i was born on __________________ in __________________. my father works as a __________________ and mother works as a __________________. i studied in __________________ school and graduated from __________________ college. i specialize in __________________ and work with __________________ as a __________________. i have been working here with __________________ . back.. take a look at the words in bold type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here what role do the words in bold play in the sentence? what if they were omitted or replaced by other words? forward.. hello, i am __________________ . i was born from __________________ into __________________. my father works on a __________________ and mother works from a __________________. i studied by __________________ school and graduated on __________________ college. i specialize through __________________ and work to __________________ from a __________________. back.. the words in bold have been replaced by others. now fill in the paragraph again and see if it still makes sense. type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here forward.. the words in bold which link a noun with the rest of the sentence are called prepositions. the relationships expressed by them in the sentence could include that of time, direction and place. they usually stand before the noun and hence the name ‘preposition’; though sometimes they are also used at the end of sentences. e.g.: what are you looking at? you must come along. prepositions could be simple (in, on, at, from, with); compound (within, into, outside, beside); prepositional phrases (in addition to, in case of, in front of, with a view to). back..

examples preposition kinds - a quick look click examples to read more. usage in, at , on, with, upon etc. examples simple preposition two word preposition, used as a single preposition, such as be + fore = before, with + in = within, out + side = outside etc. the cost of the car that i am considering is within 3 lakhs. i found her seated beside the guest of honour. compound preposition usage examples collection of words with simple prepositions. in case of any emergency, please call us. this letter is in reference to our telephonic conversation. phrase preposition usage examples
prepositions simple compound prepositional phrases

type 03 type 01 preposition types type 02 click each type to read more. on, in, at, since, for, ago, before, to, past, till, until, by time above, across, after, against, along, among, around, behind, below, beside, between, by, close to, down, from, in front of, inside, into, near, next to, off, onto, opposite, out of, outside, over, past, round, through, to, towards, under, up place/ direction others by, with, of, for, like, off, as, in spite, despite

examples prepositions of time in at on since for by during until / till from- to click examples to read more. month, year, particular time of day/month, seasons, duration when to use? we got engaged in february. let us meet tomorrow in the afternoon. examples in precise time when to use? please call the client at 4:30 p.m. examples at particular date or day when to use? reeta’s birthday party is on monday. examples on from a point of time when to use? i haven't seen him since morning. i have been working here since 2002. examples since period of time when to use? he suffered from cancer for almost 5 years. examples for up to a time period when to use? my examinations will be over by next week. by when can i expect to see her? examples by time period of occurrence of something when to use? i cannot speak to you during my office hours. examples during to say how long an action continues when to use? meat should be cooked till it turns soft and opaque. examples until / till to mark beginning and end of something when to use? geeta will be in mumbai from 23rd to 27th may. examples from - to

examples prepositions of place/ direction in at on above over by, next to, beside below towards under across through inside opposite around against among behind beyond between along click examples to read more. to indicate position in an enclosed place or limited area when to use? she is waiting for you in the hall. examples in point or specific place when to use? they decided to meet at the zoo. i keep my phone switched off at my workplace. examples at surface of something when to use? please leave the books on the table. the bird has built a nest on the roof. examples on higher than when to use? this hill station is situated 5000 metres above sea level. the plane flew above the clouds. examples above above something, more than when to use? he lost over 10 lakhs in a bet. i saw a gang of monkeys over that building. examples over near when to use? an old beggar stood next to me. she was sitting by the window watching the moon. examples by, next to, beside lower than something when to use? read the information given below. the temperature is below zero in this place. examples below movement following a line when to use? colonies of ants always move along a definite line. examples along move in the direction of when to use? let us go towards the tree. examples towards lower than or covered by when to use? there’s a piece of paper stuck under your shoe. examples under to the other point, moving over a place when to use? the dog ran across the road chasing a cat. examples across from point to point when to use? we passed through a long dark tunnel. examples through contained in when to use? look for instructions inside the container. examples inside the other side when to use? his house is on the opposite side of the road. examples opposite in a circle when to use? the cockroach is going around the cake dish. examples around in opposite direction, resting on something when to use? the painting looks good against the white background of the wall. we are driving against the directions. examples against in middle of a group when to use? she is among the top performers in our organisation. examples among at the back of when to use? the rat is hiding behind the cot. examples behind further than when to use? his house is beyond a stretch of neem trees. examples beyond located in space occupying two time frames, places, etc when to use? keep the photograph between the folds of the book. examples between

examples other prepositions by with for of like off despite click examples to read more. agent, source when to use? she was scolded by her mother for being rude to everyone. examples by accompaniment when to use? he wants to go for a movie with me. examples with shows purpose, intent when to use? i bought these chocolates for you. he reads books for pleasure. examples for association, involvement; measurement when to use? i am afraid of dogs. your symptoms suggest infection of the throat. examples of similarity, comparison when to use? he was behaving like a child, wasn’t he? like any other home maker, she served her family dutifully. examples like to indicate movement away from when to use? get off the boat immediately. examples off even though, regardless of when to use? he was selected for the contest despite his poor academic record. examples despite

activity 1 - identify all the prepositions in the passage given below. with the rising of the curtain of the it era, information technology has spread throughout the world like quick fire accelerating the global economy, thereby helping man to lead an easy and comfortable life. this revolution began first in the west and then not far behind, the east followed. scores of people rushed towards the fascinating success of this technology. a fabulous pay package with less manual work was all they could dream of. the new it companies introduced novel projects to keep up with the other companies and also to occupy their brilliant and aspiring candidates. more and more rushed towards the it mirage than it could incorporate in itself. the aspirants never dreamed of a sunset. passage prepositions continue.. yet the inevitable happened. a gloomy phase of unexpected recession heralded the abrupt climax of a glorious development and an intoxicating dream giving way to harsh realities of unemployment. the poor aspirants had to face the folly of these fabulous projects painted by the it mirage, which disappeared as fast as it could, leaving them in utter misery of unfulfilled dreams and shattered lives. in a recession, companies cut jobs to save money as their sales decrease dramatically. then they turn to technology to do tasks people used to do. eventually they realize they don’t have to re-hire the humans when business improves or at least not as many- the it sector is no exception. answer key back.. activity 1 - identify all the prepositions in the passage given below. examples differences in use of some prepositions in, at with, by between, among into, upon, to till, to beside, besides click examples to read more. when used together, ‘in’ indicates a larger place and ‘at’, a more confined space. “at” is also used for time. that is, it indicates the moment of time. we live in chennai. in, at did you meet elizabeth at her place? he lives at mylapore in chennai. “with” is connected with instrument, but “by” is connected with doer. that is, it indicates the subject. the food was served with love and warmth by mrs. rao. with, by the letter was written with red ink by chetan. she was killed by him with a knife. the table has been cleaned by the maid with a wet cloth. “between” is used only for two persons, things or groups. “among” is used for more than two persons, things and groups. there seems to be some misunderstanding between the two friends. between, among he is the tallest among his friends. “into, upon, to” are used for persons and things that are in motion, that is, when they are in action. dump the garbage into the dustbin. into, upon, to the papers were thrown upon the table. the word, “till” is used only for time and “to” for distance. the exhibition will be open till 8 p.m. till, to sometimes, the traffic jam on this road extends up to a.b. road. beside means “by the side of”. i could not see anyone beside him. (by his side) beside, besides besides means “in addition to”. what do you do for a living besides this part time job? (in addition to)

continue.. activity 3 - answers the organic content of a soil derives from the remains of dead plants and animals. these are broken down by a combination of invertebrates and microorganisms (known as the decomposers). their action results in the release of substances that can be used by plants and other microorganisms. much organic material is easily degraded, while the more resistant fraction is referred to as humus and comprises lignin together with various other macromolecules. the humus content of a soil, then, is a reflection of how favourable (or otherwise) conditions are for its decomposition; the value usually falls between 2 and 10 per cent by weight. the inorganic fraction of a soil derives from the weathering of minerals. microorganisms may be present in soils in huge numbers, mostly attached to soil particles. their numbers vary according to the availability of suitable nutrients. bacteria form the largest fraction of the microbial population, together with much smaller numbers of fungi, algae and protozoans. back.. in spite of being present in such enormous numbers, microorganisms only represent a minute percentage of the volume of most soils. fungi, although present in much smaller numbers than bacteria, form a higher proportion of the soil biomass, due to their greater size. the majority of soil microorganisms are aerobic heterotrophs, involved in the decomposition of organic substrates; thus, microbial numbers diminish greatly the further down into the soil we go, away from organic matter and oxygen. the proportion of anaerobes increases with depth, but unless the soil is waterlogged, they are unlikely to predominate. other factors affecting microbial distribution include ph, temperature and moisture. broadly speaking, neutral conditions favour bacteria, while fungi flourish in mildly acidic conditions , although extremophiles survive well outside these limits. actinomycetes are notable for their secretion of antimicrobial compounds into their surroundings, which provides an example of how the presence of one type of microorganism in a soil population can influence the growth of others. questions activity 3 - answers

compare the sentences in each column a b my mother loves me. i am loved by my mother. savita helped your sister. your sister was helped by savita. they make delicious cakes. delicious cakes are made by them. the cat will catch the mouse. the mouse will be caught by the cat. a snake bit deepika. deepika was bitten by a snake. did you lose the money? was the money lost by you? continue.. after reading the sentences thoroughly, make a list of differences that you observe in the two sets of sentences. ________________________________________________________ ________________________________________________________ ________________________________________________________ ________________________________________________________ type your text here back.. forward.. now check how close you were- in all the sentences in column a, the subject performs the action. let’s have a look at them again. the subject is underlined and the action is italicised. my mother loves me. savita helped your sister. they make delicious cakes. the cat will catch the mouse. a snake bit deepika. did you lose the money? such sentences in which the subject performs some action are said to be ‘active sentences’. forward.. back.. the objects in sentences in column a are underlined here. my mother loves me. savita helped your sister. they make delicious cakes. the cat will catch the mouse. a snake bit deepika. did you lose the money? forward.. back.. note that in all the sentences in column b, the object of the sentences in column a becomes the subject. the action is now being performed on them, in other words, they are now the recipients of the action. i am loved by my mother. your sister was helped by savita. delicious cakes are made by them. the mouse will be caught by the cat. deepika was bitten by a snake. was the money lost by you? such sentences in which the action is performed on the subject are said to be ‘passive sentences’. forward.. back.. the position of the subject and object is reversed in active and passive sentences. all the verbs in passive sentences are used in their past participle forms. (in bold) back.. a b my mother loves me. i am loved by my mother. savita helped your sister. your sister was helped by savita. they make delicious cakes. delicious cakes are made by them. the cat will catch the mouse. the mouse will be caught by the cat. a snake bit deepika. deepika was bitten by a snake. did you lose the money? was the money lost by you?

examples quick tips when to use passive? click examples to read more. when the doer or source of action is unknown. case the house was burnt. examples the cheque was issued. he was treated badly. nothing can be gained without hard work. when the doer or source of action is not important. when you do not wish to reveal who the doer is. when you talk about general truths. when you want to highlight the source of action. case examples when you are describing a procedure to someone. some sentences cannot be changed to passive at all. biology is taught to us by dr. davidson. the papers should be signed and posted to the registrar. we are going to austria.

tenses quick tips tense click tenses to read more. kavita buys a book. active voice a book is bought by kavita. passive voice simple present tense auxiliary verbs - am/ is/ are everyone admires them. they are admired by everyone. kavita is buying a book. active voice a book is being bought by kavita. passive voice present continuous tense auxiliary verbs - am being/ is being/ are being everyone is admiring them. they are being admired by everyone. mr. kushal has donated a big sum of money. active voice a big sum of money has been donated by mr. kushal . passive voice present perfect tense auxiliary verbs - has been/ have been we have found solutions to the problem. solutions to the problem have been found (by us). mr. kushal donated a big sum of money. active voice a big sum of money was donated by mr. kushal . passive voice simple past tense auxiliary verbs - was/ were we found solutions to the problem. solutions to the problem were found (by us). mr. kushal was donating a big sum of money . active voice a big sum of money was being donated by mr. kushal . passive voice past continuous tense auxiliary verbs - was being/ were being we were finding solutions to the problem. solutions to the problem were being found (by us). mr. kushal had donated a big sum of money. active voice a big sum of money had been donated by mr. kushal . passive voice past perfect tense auxiliary verbs - had been we had found solutions to the problem. solutions to the problem had been found (by us). he will open the door. active voice the door will be opened by him. passive voice simple future tense auxiliary verbs - will be + past participle form of verb will you write a letter? will a letter be written by you? you will have forgotten everything. active voice eveything will have been forgotten by you. passive voice future perfect tense auxiliary verbs - will have been the teacher will have evaluated the answer sheets. the answer sheets will have been evaluated by the teacher. keep my secret. active voice let my secret be kept (by you). passive voice imperative sentences (commands, orders, requests) auxiliary verbs - let + be praise his work. let his work be praised (by you). i can keep your secrets. active voice your secrets can be kept by me. passive voice modal auxiliaries (can/ may/ should/ ought to, etc.) auxiliary verbs - be/ been you should praise his work. his work should be praised by you.
if the subject or the object in an active voice sentence is a pronoun, (i, we, you, he, she, they, it) it changes as follows: active passive i me we us you you he him she her they them it it

activity 3 - answers 1. soak gelatin in ½ cup water for 5 minutes and keep aside. 2. beat cream with sugar till fluffy. 3. beat hung curd till smooth. add cheese spread and whip till smooth. 4. mix the whipped cream and curd mixture. 5. heat gelatin on low flame. you should stir it continuously. then add it to the curd-cream mixture. gelatin is soaked in ½ cup water for 5 minutes and kept aside. cream is beaten with sugar till fluffy. hung curd is beaten till smooth. cheese spread is added and whipped till smooth. the whipped cream and curd mixture are mixed. gelatin is heated on low flame. it should be stirred continuously. then it is added to the curd-cream mixture. continue.. 7. chill it in the freezer for 20 minutes. 8. meanwhile, cut a thick slice from the bottom of a sponge cake. sprinkle milk on it. 9. next, spread mango crush on it. 10. pour the curd-cream mixture over the cake and chill for 4 hours. back.. questions 6. add mango puree and mix well. add more sugar if required. mango puree is added and mixed well. more sugar is added if required. it is chilled in the freezer for 20 minutes. meanwhile, a thick slice from the bottom of a sponge cake is cut. milk is sprinkled on it. next, mango crush is spread on it. the curd-cream mixture is poured over the cake and chilled for 4 hours.

example read these examples what is a modal verb? click example to read more. i could not attend the wedding as i was not in town. (main verb included) (main verb omitted) i could not the wedding as i was not in town. she should clean the room today. she should the room today. they may take us for granted. they may us for granted. may i use your pen? may i your pen? everyone ought to follow the rules. everyone ought to the rules. he will travel only by road. he will only by road.

modals did you observe that verbs like ‘could, should, may, will’ cannot make sense without the help of another main verb? these verbs are often used to express modality such as- probabililty shirin may not enjoy this movie. ability i can type very fast. request may i come in? compulsion we must prepare the report by tomorrow. such supporting verbs used along with the main verb to attach expressions such as obligation, belief, etc. to your statements are modal auxiliaries or simply auxiliary verbs.

quick tips (verb+s) form of verb is not used with a modal. for example- she goes to her mother’s place. she will go to her mother’s place. (correct) she will goes to her mother’s place. (incorrect) their negative forms are formed by the simple addition of ‘not’. e.g: sameer will begin the session tomorrow. sameer will not begin the session tomorrow. continue.. their forms are never changed for different tenses or number by addition of -s or -ed etc. for example, it is wrong to use cans, wills, shoulds to express modality. except for ‘ought to’, they are never followed by ‘to’. they differ in meaning and usage when used in different contexts. for example, i can lift this heavy sack. (ability) can you help me? (request) back..

example use it to express… & examples can could may might will would shall should must ought to click the example to read more. ability use it to express… can you drive a car? examples can you can be caught easily. can you buy me these flowers? can i invite my friends for lunch? possibility request asking permission (less formally) asking permission (usually more politely) use it to express… could i come at 8 in the morning? examples could though i was never good at science, i could solve mathematical problems quickly. they could have been accommodated in the house. ability (in the past) possibility asking permission (more formal) use it to express… may i explain it to you? examples may raman may not eat in this restaurant. he may be feeling bad now, but it’s all for his own good. possibility or probability substitute for although possibility use it to express… i might not be able to transfer money as early as tomorrow. examples might might i borrow your scooter? you might like to join our club. polite permission suggestions note: might is used to express weak possibility. certainty use it to express… sooner or later, everyone will know the truth. examples will siddharth will quit his job soon. will you go shopping with me? prediction request (informal) past of ‘will’ use it to express… i hope it would not have bothered you much. examples would if reactions weren’t catalysed, they would proceed extremely slowly. would you like some coffee? conditions request or offer future action use it to express… i shall be appearing for auditions next week. examples shall shall i make egg curry and rice for dinner? shall i help you in the kitchen? suggestion offer advice use it to express… unruly children should be sent to hostel. examples should i should perform well in the examination this time. they should be here anytime. mild obligation conclusion certainty use it to express… rishi must have been hurt by your remarks. examples must sheela must see a cardiologist at the earliest. strong advice obligation the company must meet market standards. obligation - use interchangeably with should use it to express… we ought to cut down our expenditure on petrol. examples ought to dinesh ought to handle his team diplomatically.

activity 1 in the passage given below, fill in the blanks with suitable modal verbs. nearly a billion people in the world do not have access to clean drinking water. if the government and the community do not look into it, the number of those who ___________ be badly in need of potable water ___________ swell up to a mind-boggling 2.5 billion in the next few years. what’s more, a majority of these people ___________ be in india. calling for people's participation, the prime minister emphasised the need for a nationwide movement that ___________ involve ngo's, panchayati raj institutions and the citizens to manage the county's water resources. this ___________ help in introducing rainwater harvesting as one measure that stands out for its "simplicity, efficacy and affordability". in the distribution of water resources too, we see strange paradoxes- while millions struggle to get a pitcher of potable water, there is another india where people tend to waste and contaminate it, just because it ___________ be easily available to them. these two indians ___________ not co-exist. the government is already promoting the rain-water harvesting program through watershed management, artificial recharge of ground water and rooftop water harvesting. the program has assumed significance, keeping in mind the dropping ground water levels during the recent drought. the schools ___________ be asked to encourage rainwater harvesting too. this ___________ also help to inculcate awareness among students about storing and economical use of water. people have succeeded in harvesting rain-water in delhi including the rashtrapati bhawan, chandigarh, rajasthan, gujarat, maharashtra, tamil nadu. in the years ahead, it seems drinking water ___________ become a luxury that may be afforded by few. thus, every citizen ___________ feel responsible for conserving every drop of water through rainwater harvesting. answers

relative & interrogative pronouns continue

example usage & examples.. who that what which click the example to read more. used interrogatively and in relative clauses for persons. usage who gave you this brilliant idea? examples who the boy who stole the money was punished. substitute who for he/ she/ i/ we and check if the sentence sounds correct. for identifying a specific person or thing; usually gives essential information about them. usage here’s the gift that you asked for. examples that he bought the medicines that were prescribed to him. usage this is what i have been hunting for. examples what what are you going to do with all these old newspapers? what is the book all about? in questions, asking for information. sometimes as relative pronoun to show relation. usage which dressing do you like for salads? examples which please forward the mail which she sent you yesterday. asks answers from a limited range of possible answers. as a relative pronoun used only for things; usually provides nonessential information (separated by commas).
the gist... who person what specific thing where place or position when time which specific thing (from a narrow choice) why reason how manner

vocabulary start

vocabulary refers to the sum total of all the words of a language. it could also mean the sum total of the words of a language that a person knows and uses. a good vocabulary is essential for effective communication and gaining knowledge from literary sources, both oral and written. a good vocabulary facilitates reading comprehension. a person may know a word, but knowing is not equivalent to recognizing or using it. thus, to build a good vocabulary it is important to be able to recognise and use words correctly in communication. continue.. quick tips choosing appropriate words to express ourselves is something we all want to do; and this comes along when we build a good vocabulary. sometimes we have some ideas in our mind, but the right word just doesn’t click at the right time, doesn’t that happen with most of us? or you may be jotting your ideas in some words which just don’t suffice, you feel the need for a better substitute. back.. that’s where a good vocabulary comes into play. this module will teach you some frequently used words and the activities will help you make your guesses more accurate. quick tips

make the dictionary your close friend. make sure to choose a good one such as oxford’s, chamber’s and webster’s. also ensure your dictionary includes word usage as well because sometimes it’s not enough to know the meaning alone. never put it off till tomorrow. if you come across a new word, make a note of it and head for the dictionary as soon as possible. read a lot. make sure you read from a quality source- free of grammatical errors and rich in challenging words. look for clues from the surrounding of the word that you don’t know. (the exercises in this module will help you with this) continue.. quick tips get into the habit of writing. to start with, you could maintain a personal diary. writing necessitates proper articulation and you will find and learn more and more words in this process. play games. vocabulary building doesn’t have to be cumbersome at all. play online vocabulary building games or pair up with your friend to make learning fun. get a thesaurus. a thesaurus is a book that gives you synonyms just as a dictionary is a collection of word meanings. learning synonymous words is also a good way of boosting your vocabulary. use what you learn. words are not to be learnt and stored. they only add up to your vocabulary when you use them frequently and correctly in what you write and speak. have fun with the exercises coming up! back.. quick tips

guess what i mean? deducing meanings of words from the context in which they are used is the easiest way to grasp new words. the hints surrounding the word could give you information about its- 1. synonym (words with similar meaning) e.g. : melancholy- sad, miserable, jocular- funny, playful 2. antonym (words with opposite meaning) e.g. : morbid- cheerful, happy 3. other details citing examples or evidences in support of the word 4. formation of the word (prefix and suffix) encapsulated- within a capsule look out for such indications and allow them to guide you to deduce meanings. let’s take up some examples now.

case 2 case 3 case 4 case 1 case synonymous words in the sentence antonymous words in the sentence other details giving more information about the word looking for word formation click each case to read more. please keep your speech concise and try to finish it within 15 minutes as we are already running short of time. example possible deduction concise could mean brief synonymous words in the sentence i love visiting my aunt who always welcomes me cordially, but her daughter is equally cold and unwelcoming. example possible deduction cordially could mean with warmth and affection antonymous words in the sentence there is dearth of good hearted people these days. the world is full of only those who think of no one except themselves. example possible deduction dearth could mean shortage other details giving more information about the word this is the most malodorous flower that i’ve come across. example possible deduction malodorous could mean something that gives bad odor. looking for word formation

communicate - get your ideas across technically defined, communication is a process of conveying information to someone by written, spoken or non verbal means, the end result of which should ideally be understanding. you call the customer care cell of a mobile service provider to seek help for the non functioning of 3g services in your phone. read the two conversations and decide who addressed your query in a better way.

if you are able to communicate effectively, be assured that you possess one of the most important life skills. communication is simply the act of information transfer via various means such as vocal (using voice); written (books, magazines, websites); visual (pictures, maps, charts or graphs) or non-verbal (using body language, gestures, the tone and pitch of voice). how well this information is transmitted and received tells you how good your communication skills are. at workplaces, poor communication skills result in loss of time and resources due to ineffective transmission of messages or mis-communication. developing your communication skills helps you in all aspects of life. the ability to be able to communicate accurately and effectively should not be overlooked. it’s never too late to begin working on your communication skills. this module gives you some promising tips that you must follow to whet your communication abilities.

quick tips perfecting my communication skills it’s a two way process the key to good communication is not just speaking effectively, it is also about being a good listener. before speaking, always be patient enough to allow the speaker to finish. continue.. do not hurry when someone speaks, do not interrupt in between. allow their point to be finished and then speak up. forward.. back.. follow etiquette always make sure to keep your language free of slang. use professional language; avoid mixing vernacular speech. forward.. back.. plan beforehand plan well what you are about to put forth. this helps you avoid repetitions which make your listeners less interested in you. also, you wouldn't be missing any important points on your mind. back..

quick tips honing my communication skills am i confident enough? confidence helps you communicate more successfully. it builds trust and relationship. you may have all the skills in the world but if you are not confident enough in convincing people about them, they are of no use to you. continue.. keep it short you may be having some spare time to talk a trifle too much, but others may not! convey your message in simple words in the most concise manner. forward.. back.. do i maintain eye contact? maintaining eye contact is a good sign of effective communication. it helps you connect straight to the listener and gets you the attention you deserve. avoiding eye contact shows your discomfort and you end up getting lesser attention from the listeners. forward.. back.. make it crystal clear after you’ve finished delivering, make it a point to ask people if they need any clarifications from you. this helps to avoid chances of misunderstanding which may arise due to lack of clarity in the first place. forward.. back.. focus on simplicity your aim to communicate is to make yourself clear and understood to the people you are addressing. avoid using confusing statements, double meaning words or very difficult words to impress your audience. getting your idea across should be your prime focus and make it as uncomplicated as possible. forward.. back.. make the atmosphere light your body language speaks volumes about how good you are at communication. make the process pleasant; avoid use of harsh words. back..

tab 03 tab 01 stress and emphasis tab 02 click each tab to read more. in any language, stress refers to the relative emphasis laid on some syllables. in a word, not all syllables are stressed equally. syllables are stressed by making them sound different from the other syllables in the word by differences in their- pitch loudness length 1. 2. 3. word stress on incredible incredible april april carrot carrot machine machine humid humid i am going i am going similarly, words in a sentence are also stressed. consider the example- i am going - (who is going?) the words in bold denote the word(s) in the sentence which has been stressed. though comprising the same words, these sentences may be used in different situations such as- i am going - (when the action being performed by the speaker is more important)

in written text, what do you do when you want to highlight a point or a single word? you use techniques like bold font, underlining, coloring the text and so on. it is important to know when and how much to stress particular words relative to the rest of the sentence because in speech, the only means of highlighting a word is to stress its pronunciation. thus, depending on what kind of message the speaker wants to convey, the pattern of stress can be chosen by him accordingly.

punctuation punctuation is a set of standard marks used in written language to indicate the positions of stress and the general structure of the sentences. the same sentence with different kinds of punctuation marks could elicit varying meanings. for example, though both the sentences are composed of the same words in exactly the same sequence, sentence 1 tells you rohit is lamenting over something. the second one doesn’t make complete sense. “perhaps”, cried rohit. perhaps cried rohit.

punctuation marks correct punctuation is a must for comprehensible and effective writing. following is a list of the commonly used punctuation marks along with their usage. punctuation marks usage examples to separate portions of a sentence such as clauses comma i was, however, firm with my decision. to indicate a pause the hungry, sly fox attacked the pups. to separate items in a list temperature, humidity and soil factors determine the vegetation of a place. to indicate the end of a sentence i reached chennai an hour ago. placed after abbreviations she wants to buy the latest android phone. period 1 2 3 4 5 lemon, gooseberries, oranges, etc. are good sources of vitamin c. punctuation marks correct punctuation is a must for comprehensible and effective writing. following is a list of the commonly used punctuation marks along with their usage. punctuation marks usage examples to show strong feeling semi colon alas! we lost by two wickets. hurry up! to separate clauses related to each other and are equally important hurry up!!!! (incorrect) to separate lists which are already separated by commas i waited for three hours; he didn’t turn up. 1 3 4 5 exclamation mark commanding do not use more than one in a row they represent another special case; most of them are essentially submicroscopic. fried fish tastes best with tartar dip, cheese sauce, green curry; fried chicken with garlic sauce, mint salsa and flavoured mayonnaise. punctuation marks correct punctuation is a must for comprehensible and effective writing. following is a list of the commonly used punctuation marks along with their usage. punctuation marks usage examples after a sentence to introduce a new word or clause colon answer these questions related to what you studied: what, why and how? question mark 1 2 4 5 used at the end of an interrogative sentence may i help you? how about lunch at the new restaurant close to your office? punctuation marks correct punctuation is a must for comprehensible and effective writing. following is a list of the commonly used punctuation marks along with their usage. punctuation marks usage examples to quote what was said by someone quotation marks “how far is ooty form here?” enquired the tourist. to highlight a word or phrase the “reward” he received was just what he deserved. for titles of articles, poems, reports, lessons in a book the music album of “chennai express” has been launched. to show belongingness this movie is my husband’s all time favourite. when words are abbreviated by omission of some letters we haven’t heard from her yet. apostrophe 1 2 3 5 punctuation marks correct punctuation is a must for comprehensible and effective writing. following is a list of the commonly used punctuation marks along with their usage. punctuation marks usage examples with prefixes hyphen the book throws light on the pre-industrialization era. to join or separate words it was only a make-believe marriage. in a sentence to distinguish a clause tonight’s special – fish chips with creamy dip. 1 2 3 4

one of the basics in a business is learning proper business telephone etiquette. telephone is an integral part of any business and is usually the first point of contact with clients and customers. telephone etiquette ensures you leave a good impact on your callers. it indicates your readiness and ability to professionally handle customers. thus, it is imperative for employees to have a good understanding of telephone etiquette. answering a business call at your workplace involves a different approach. this module introduces you to some of the basics of telephone etiquette along with some model lines which you can practice in your day-to-day telephonic conversations.

case 2 case 3 case 4 case 5 case 6 case 7 case 1 case answering a call making a call handling complaints over the phone wrong number! place ‘em on hold / transfer calls taking / leaving messages how to end click each case to read more. answer within three rings. dos don'ts understand and learn if there is a standard protocol for answering calls in your organization. open the conversation with a polite greeting. show that the caller is important for you by asking their name. ask how you can be of help to them. speak too loud or too feebly to be heard by the caller. multitask in the midst of the call, the caller might get angry if he found out or you may lose an important message. be clear and confident in what you speak. answering a call keep your promises if you need to call someone at a fixed time. plan beforehand what you are going to discuss. identify yourself and your purpose of calling to the person who answers. forget to leave your number and time when you can be contacted in case the person you wanted to speak with wasn’t available. making a call dos don'ts be patient and polite to the person who wants his problem to be attended to. be a good listener. understand the nature of problem and express regrets courteously for the inconvenience caused to them. state in clear words how you propose to deal with the problem they have. interrupt the speaker until he has finished explaining his trouble. delay taking action to solve the matter. give impractical solutions just to appease the caller. get into an argument with the caller. handling complaints over the phone dos don'ts apologize to the person if you have reached a wrong number. be considerate if you happen to answer a wrong number. argue with the person that you have dialled the correct number. speak rudely and humiliate the caller for having called a wrong number. wrong number! dos don'ts if you’re answering for someone, note down the message clearly without skipping any of the details such as the caller’s name, designation, purpose of communication (only if he wishes to reveal), the time, date and other details provided by him. read out the message again if you are unsure about something. scribble notes untidily. scream into the answering machine. to leave a voice message into an answering machine, begin with a greeting, followed by your name and message, spoken clearly and slowly. keep them to the point. use slang terms while leaving a message. clutter your message with too many confusing details. taking / leaving messages dos don'ts always ask for permission before putting someone on hold. return to the call if it’s taking longer than expected and ask if they’d like to be called by you. place on hold for doing some of your tasks. make anyone hold the call for over 60 seconds. be polite and thank them for having held the call. let the person know when you’re transferring their call to the desired person. transfer calls when the desired person isn't available or doesn’t want to take the call at the moment. place ‘em on hold / transfer calls dos don'ts end with polite words. hang up without even saying a goodbye. how to end dos don'ts suggested opening lines good morning. thanks for calling abc. this is (your name). how can i assist you? may i know your name please? this is (your name) from xyz. how can i help you? answering a call suggested lines this is (your name) from xyz. could you please connect me to the production department? i’m calling from xyz to confirm today’s meeting with mr. asdf. this is (your name) calling from the it department of xyz. i called to check if mr. z is available on 21st of may to deliver a program in our company. making a call suggested lines i am extremely sorry for the inconvenience caused, we are working on the problem and it shall be fixed in two to three hours. please bear with us as there is some technical problem, our team is doing its best to make repairs. would you mind explaining the issue in detail? handling complaints over the phone suggested lines you seem to have dialled an incorrect number. i am so sorry, i didn’t realise i had dialed the wrong number. sorry to bother you, i think i have dialed the number incorrectly. wrong number! suggested lines could you repeat the number, please? hello, you have reached xyz. please leave your name and number and we’ll get in touch with you shortly. mr. x is not at his desk. would you like to leave any message for him? could you spell the name, please? taking / leaving messages suggested lines please stay on line as i transfer your call to the concerned department/person. it’s taking longer than expected; would you mind leaving your number so that mr. x can call you back? thanks for holding the line. place ‘em on hold / transfer calls suggested lines it was a pleasure talking to you. thanks for calling, sir. how to end is there anything else i can help you with? if you need further assistance, please call back.
writing effective emails start

emails that are well composed help you get your ideas across in the most effective way. correspondence by email is one of the most preferred forms of business communication because of the convenience with which they can be sent and received. they simplify a lot of your tasks by offering features like mass communication (using cc option), attachment of numerous documents, maintenance of contact book, etc. in this module, our emphasis will be on learning to write effective formal mails, which follow a set of rules you will be familiarized with here. some sample letters have been provided to make the idea of effective correspondence clear. in addition to this, you need to practice writing some of them yourself in the exercises at the end of the module.

quick tips - business emails - dos and don'ts follow these simple yet essential tips to make your emails incontrovertibly effective. being formal understand for whom the mail is being written. if the correspondence requires you to be very formal, stick to it. continue.. when not to email when you have a long list of things to be discussed and passed on, avoid emailing. such discussions are better held over phone. when urgent information needs to be sent, do not use emails for the purpose. back.. forward.. a proper reply reply to mails in a timely manner. do not forget to apologise if you fail to do so. when the reply needs to be short, avoid using one liners like ‘ok’ or ‘thanks’. do not hit the ‘reply all’ button if the message isn’t meant for others to see. make use of ‘bcc’ option to maintain privacy of email ids. forward.. back.. a good beginning salutation is the first thing the recipient notices on opening the mail. avoid addressing the person with his first name. when addressing a female, avoid writing mrs. or miss, take the safe way and address them as ms. when you do not know the name of the person you are writing to, dear sir or madam will suffice. another way could be to write the name of the department if it is known, but keep it only as the last option. back.. forward.. getting to the point stick to your purpose of correspondence. keep your letters short and to the point. write complete meaningful sentences. keep your mail free of slang and informal greetings. the mail should appear neat and not cluttered by jargon, emoticons, etc. compose separate mails to address separate issues. forward.. back.. sensible signatures signatures include your name, designation and contact details, website url and they save you the trouble of typing them every time you write a mail. avoid including unnecessary quotes in your signature. back.. forward.. no errors please check for grammatical errors, wrong spellings and improper punctuation. don’t ever write anything in capitals as it appears very repelling. forward.. back.. the subject sending a mail without a subject line shows rashness on your part and your mails stand a good chance of being ignored. a subject also facilitates searching for the right mail when you have multiple mails from a common sender. keep the subject brief and to the point. some examples include - application for the post of____, final reminder for enrolment of_____, invitation to join x’s network, request for a revised quote and so on. forward.. back.. formatting avoid multiple fonts, colored text, graphics and background patterns. use italics and bold only to emphasize certain text. always use sentence case for composing mails. back.. forward.. be polite be gentle and polite in writing a mail. use words like please, thank you, could generously. back..

examples samples when you write an official mail, you would find that some aspects such as complaints, apologies, applications, etc. are frequently encountered. below given are some suggestions on how to put these into proper words. note that these may be just tags or phrases and you should use them in appropriate sentences in the correct context. use these phrases and sentences to form letters of your own in the letter writing exercise that follows. click examples to learn more. salutation dear sir/ madam, mr. x or ms. y case suggested lines opening lines case suggested lines this is in response to your application we would like to inform you that further to our telephonic conversation thanks for the consideration we are pleased to associate with with reference to your last mail apologies case suggested lines we offer our sincere apologies for i am writing to apologize for the confusion please accept our heartfelt apologies clarify details case suggested lines we request you to throw light on the following it seems some misunderstanding has been created let us clarify complaints case suggested lines this was definitely not what we were expecting the service quality has been way below standards we are disappointed with it would have been better if your staff has let us down making requests case suggested lines you are kindly requested to please attend to the issue at the earliest closing lines case suggested lines thanking you in anticipation, best regards looking forward to a prompt response i can be contacted over the phone during office hours we look forward to a flourishing relationship in the future attachments case suggested lines please find the attachment the requested document is attached herewith please find enclosed

letter of recommendation by a supervisor for his junior to study in a university abroad. sample letter dear sir, as the senior programmer of incarnate solutions, it gives me pleasure to write this letter of recommendation for mr. alfred, who has been working with me for the last five years. he has been a brilliant programmer and an asset to our organization. i would like to take this opportunity to recommend him for pursuing his higher studies at your university. until recently, i have been his immediate supervisor for a number of projects undertaken by our company. i found him to be consistently pleasant, tackling all assignments with dedication. alfred has excellent communication skills. also, he is extremely organized and quick to volunteer whenever required. it is for these reasons that i offer high recommendations for mr. alfred without reservation. i recommend him very strongly for admission with suitable financial assistance. if you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me. sincerely, gopal verma sr. software developer incarnate solutions

reading comprehension what i read?’ appreciate ‘do i really start

why learning to read and understand what we are reading is one of the necessary steps towards literacy. reading without understanding is like staring at words without knowing what they are about. reading comprehension is the ability to understand what you read. reading comprehension is what allows the reader to interact with the text in a meaningful way. it is a direct result of reading fluency. consider the example- don kirkpatrick's contribution on evaluation techniques has been the first step towards making training a comprehensive result based process. his contribution on four-levels of evaluation has helped us a lot in accomplishing our project’s objective.

a) the field of training. b) to accomplish our project’s objective. c) four-level of evaluation to make training result based. based on your understanding, answer these questions- 1. don kirkpatrick contributed to a) advanced field. b) result based process. c) project based objective. 2. before his contributions, training was not a a) don kirkpatrick’s four level evaluation model hadn’t been devised. b) evaluation techniques hadn’t been the first step. c) none of these. 3. accomplishing our project’s objective wouldn’t have been possible if if you weren’t able to answer all of these questions, you probably need to go back to the text and give it a more thorough reading.

reading without comprehension is not reading. if you can read and still not interpret what you’ve read, you need to start whetting your comprehension skills. that’s what our next module’s all about - making you comprehend what you read. like any other skill, reading comprehension too can be acquired by practising. follow the tips given in this module and also practise some passages to make your interpretations more precise.

quick tips 1. inculcate reading as a habit read as much as you can from as many sources as possible. reading at bed-time is a must for those who do not find time during their busy work hours. make books your best friends. get a library membership if possible to have access to quality books. continue.. 2. fluency is a must fluency is the ability to read quickly and accurately with ease. it is important from comprehension point of view because those who do read fluently can concentrate better on the comprehension part as they are not disrupted by words. if you’re not fluent in reading, you will have to take time to read individual words and split sentences into several bits. in the process, all of your attention gets diverted towards reading properly and there is little room for understanding. get into the habit of reading your text aloud. this will let you understand what portions of the text you are getting stuck at. highlight those areas and read again with more attention and emphasis. use the chart given here to understand your progress. back.. forward.. back.. attempt number time that i took number of places where interrupted number of points that i recall number of words i didn’t understand type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here type your text here reading fluency chart forward.. 3. speed reading reading reasonably fast helps you when you are required to skim through text at a short notice. do not worry if you can’t read too fast. speed reading is a good skill to possess, but it isn’t really an absolute requirement. what is more important is fluency, which will automatically make your reading speed well above average. also, there are situations where reading fast is not recommended, for instance, legal documents, important files, text to be proofread, etc. here, comprehension, regardless of the reading speed is mandatory. thus, keep your speed flexible conforming to the demand of the situation. forward.. back.. 4. take a step at a time practising comprehension passages is a good way of improving comprehension skills. start with simple text where you can answer all related questions effortlessly. once you are confident to move to the next level, head for it. all this is bound to take some time depending on individual capabilities; do not expect overnight results. if you take up challenging texts in the first place, you may end up being disappointed. back.. forward.. 5. frame questions in your mind after you have read your passage, pen down all the questions that come to your mind. with every little detail provided in the passage, you could raise a couple of relevant questions. underline difficult words, phrases and idiomatic expressions and try to search their meaning. if you are able to answer most of the questions raised, you can be sure that you have understood it all well. back.. forward.. 6. knotty words as discussed in the vocabulary section, new and difficult words are not problematic if you can identify hints and guess their meaning. refer to vocabulary section for more details and exercises. forward.. back.. 7. visualising and note making after having read the extract, form a mental picture of the situation that you just read about. in reading comprehension, imagination is a good tool as it helps understand text better. this is because images leave a deeper impact on recalling efficiency as compared to something that is heard or read. put all the pieces of information in the paragraph together to make a complete picture. make subtle notes of the important highlights which are decisive in your comprehension of the text. forward.. back.. 8. what’s it all about? every passage revolves around an idea, which is the central theme that it speaks about. it may not be expressed in one word or sentence; you will have to understand the whole thing before you can judge what the main idea is. the main theme of the passage is always backed by details to support it. look for examples, facts, opinions, types, supporting ideas, conclusions, comparisons, statistics, etc. which define the tone of the passage. forward.. back.. back.. 8. what’s it all about? (cont..) central idea figures comparisons inferences assumptions causes examples

passage # 1 now read these practice passages carefully and fill in the progress chart each time you read them. then mark the correct answers based on your understanding of the passage. questions many aspects of our everyday lives are influenced in some way by microorganisms. they play a pivotal role in our environment, as well as their ability both to cause and cure infectious diseases. in addition, they are responsible for the production of much of what we eat and drink, synthesize industrially useful chemicals and can even extract precious metals from the earth. to the general public, the association of microorganisms and food conjures up negative images of rotten fruit or food poisoning. on reflection, many people may remember that yeast is involved in bread and beer production, but how many realise that microorganisms play a part in the manufacture of soy sauce, pepperoni and even chocolate and contribute to many of the contents of our shopping baskets? the production of foodstuffs as a result of microbial fermentation reactions predates recorded history. the accidental discovery that such foods were less susceptible to spoilage than fresh foods must have made them an attractive proposition to people in those far-off days. of course, until relatively recent times, nothing was known of the part played by microorganisms, so the production of beer, cheese and vinegar would not have been the carefully controlled processes that are used today. indeed, it was only with the development of isolation techniques towards the end of the nineteenth century, that it became possible to use pure cultures in food production for the first time. the fermentation of foodstuffs, hitherto an art, became a science. there is evidence that alcoholic drinks, including beer and wine, were being produced thousands of years before the christian era, making them among the earliest known examples of the exploitation of microorganisms by humans. ethanol results from the fermentation process, because the conversion of sugar to carbon dioxide and water is incomplete. although, in principle, wine can be made from almost any fruit juice with a high sugar content, the vast majority of commercially produced wines derive from the fermentation of the sugar present in grapes. such fermentation reactions may be initiated by yeasts naturally found on the grape skin; however the results of such fermentations are erratic and may be unpalatable. in commercial winemaking the must (juice) resulting from the crushed grapes is treated with sulphur dioxide to kill the natural microflora and then inoculated with the yeast saccharomyces cerevisiae. the production of red and white wines differ in certain details, but share the main stages of crushing the grapes, fermenting their sugar content into alcohol and ageing to allow flavour development. so the next time you have a sip of alcohol, be grateful to the millions of these tiny factories that worked hard to give you the product you are enjoying!
