passage # 2 questions the hereditary nature of every living organism is defined by its genome, which consists of a long sequence of nucleic acids that provides the information needed to construct the organism. we use the term "information" because the genome does not itself perform any active role in building the organism; rather it is the sequence of the individual subunits (bases) of the nucleic acid that determines hereditary features. by a complex series of interactions, this sequence is used to produce all the proteins of the organism in the appropriate time and place. the proteins either form part of the structure of the organism or have the capacity to build the structures or to perform the metabolic reactions necessary for life. the genome contains the complete set of hereditary information for any organism. physically the genome may be divided into a number of different nucleic acid molecules. functionally it may be divided into genes. each gene is a sequence within the nucleic acid that represents a single protein. each of the discrete nucleic acid molecules comprising the genome may contain a large number of genes. genomes for living organisms may contain as few as 500 genes for a mycoplasma, a type of bacterium to as many as 40,000 for man. the basic behavior of the gene was defined by mendel more than a century ago. summarized in his two laws, the gene was recognized as a "particulate factor" that passes unchanged from parent to progeny. a gene may exist in alternative forms. these forms are called alleles. in diploid organisms, which have two sets of chromosomes, one copy of each chromosome is inherited from each parent. this is the same behavior that is displayed by genes. one of the two copies of each gene is the paternal allele (inherited from the father), the other is the maternal allele (inherited from the mother). the equivalence led to the discovery that chromosomes in fact carry the genes.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Audio not required.

ACTIVITY 1

Read these sentences and decide whether they pertain to actions of past, present or future. Fill the answer table provided.

·What was your basis of categorizing the sentences as past, present and future?

In all languages, time is divided into 3 frames-

·Now- refers to the current time (present tense)
·Past- refers to the time before now (past tense)
·Future- refers to the time after now (future tense)

In this module, we will understand-

·What tenses are
·Regular verbs
·Irregular verbs
·When and how to use the past, present and future tenses
·Correct usage of verb forms in different tenses


·As you can observe in the table above, to denote different tense forms, verb forms need to be changed.
·Depending on the time of action, verbs need to be changed in various forms such as their past, present participle and past participle. Helping verbs like ‘will, have, be’ are also used for denoting different tenses.
·Therefore, let us first understand regular and irregular verbs and how their forms are changed.

Regular and Irregular verbs

Regular verbs

Verbs that form their past and past participle forms by adding -d or -ed to their base forms are regular verbs.

When you want to change the base form of a regular verb to its past form, suffix -d to those verbs that end with a vowel and -ed to those ending with a consonant. For example,

·Please explain your statement.
·He explained his statement.

Irregular verbs

·The difference between a regular and an irregular verb is in the way how their past and past participle forms are formed.
·The simple past and past participle forms of irregular verbs could take various forms, with no regularity in their pattern.
·The most common errors that we make with irregular verbs are to add -d or -ed to form their past tenses. E.g.: swimmed, teached, etc.
·Irregular verbs do not follow the standard rules of verb forms. Therefore there is no other way of avoiding mistakes with irregular verbs than to learn them all.
·Go through as many of them as possible along with their past and participle forms.

·In a sentence, we essentially include two parts-
·We identify a person or a thing. (the subject)
·Mention something about the person or thing. (the predicate)

For example-

·The mountain is covered with snow.
·In this sentence, what we are speaking about is the mountain, which makes it the subject; what is being spoken about the mountain is that it is covered with snow- this is the predicate of the sentence.
·Thus, all sentences consist essentially of two parts- the subject and the predicate.

Consider the same example again-

·(The mountain is covered) with snow.
·The part of the sentence enclosed in brackets is a complete sentence in itself, with a subject (the mountain) and predicate (is covered).
·In addition to the subject and predicate, there is a complement which gives you more information.
·Thus, a predicate could be a single word verb or consist of complements which tell us more about what the subject does.

Identifying subject and predicate

·Many a times, the subject is not as easily identifiable as in the previous examples.
·Here comes the prince.
·This is the sweetest song I’ve ever heard.
·In such cases, the subject can be spotted by asking questions 'who' or 'what'.
·Here, the answer to who comes is ‘the prince’, therefore it is the subject.
·Sometimes when a sentence is used for giving a command, such as in an imperative sentence, the subject isn’t quite visible. For e.g.:
·Take your seat.
·Here the hidden but obvious subject is ‘you’.
·In a sentence, there could be more than one subject joined by and, or, either, neither…nor.

For example-

·Kangaroos and koala bears are marsupials.
·Is your uncle or aunt coming?
·Thus, to identify a subject, try to understand who or what the sentence talks about. This will be clear from the exercises that follow.

·Having plural subjects with singular verbs or the reverse, results in confusing sentences, which fail to convey your meaning. This becomes particularly important when long phrases separate the subject from the verb. Understanding subject-verb agreement helps you create clear sentences that the reader or listener will understand.
·The simple and only rule to remember in subject-verb agreement is ‘singular verb for singular subject and plural verb for plural subject.’
·Before learning the rules for subject-verb agreement, let us briefly take up what a subject in a sentence means.

What is a subject?
A subject is the ‘head-word’ in a sentence. The subject is the most important word in a sentence. The subject may also be treated as ‘naming word’. That is, the subject may be the names of the persons, places or pronouns.

·What is a Predicate?

A predicate is the verb or verbal group in a sentence. The verb is also known as a saying part, it tells the action done by the subject.

·In the sentences, the number of the subject (singular or plural) matches with the number of verb.
·There are some definite rules governing the agreement of subjects with verbs which will be taken up here.
·The plurals of verbs are usually their base forms themselves. E.g.: give, make, etc. Their singular forms are usually formed by suffixing -s to them.
·The easiest and usually the most reliable way to identify subjects is to ask and answer the questions ‘who’ and ‘what’. For example,
·Rohan is going to Brazil. (Who is going?- Rohan)
·It is also important to keep in mind the ‘person’ - 1st, 2nd or 3rd that is being used in the sentence.

PERSON - Who is being spoken about?

·1st person or the self (I, me, we)
·2nd person or the person spoken to (you)
·3rd person or the person spoken about (he, she, him, her, they, them).
·Knowledge of ‘persons’ is important from Subject verb agreement point of view as verbs change form with different persons.
·As can be seen from the table-
·Verbs are always plural with 1st and 2nd persons.
·They take singular and plural forms with 3rd person depending on whether the subject is singular or plural. E.g.
·Farida wakes up at 5 everyday. (singular)
·They wake up at 5 everyday. (plural)

The words in bold which link a noun with the rest of the sentence are called prepositions.

The relationships expressed by them in the sentence could include that of time, direction and place.

They usually stand before the noun and hence the name ‘preposition’; though sometimes they are also used at the end of sentences. E.g.:

What are you looking at?

You must come along.

Prepositions could be simple (in, on, at, from, with); compound (within, into, outside, beside); prepositional phrases (in addition to, in case of, in front of, with a view to).

In all the sentences in column A, the subject performs the action.

Let’s have a look at them again. The subject is underlined and the action is italicised.

·My mother loves me.
·Savita helped your sister.
·They make delicious cakes.
·The cat will catch the mouse.
·A snake bit Deepika.
·Did you lose the money?

Such sentences in which the subject performs some action are said to be ‘active sentences’.

The objects in sentences in column A are underlined here.

·My mother loves me.
·Savita helped your sister.
·They make delicious cakes.
·The cat will catch the mouse.
·A snake bit Deepika.
·Did you lose the money?

Note that in all the sentences in column B, the object of the sentences in column A becomes the subject.

The action is now being performed on them, in other words, they are now the recipients of the action.

·I am loved by my mother.
·Your sister was helped by Savita.
·Delicious cakes are made by them.
·The mouse will be caught by the cat.
·Deepika was bitten by a snake.
·Was the money lost by you?

Such sentences in which the action is performed on the subject are said to be ‘passive sentences’.

The position of the subject and object is reversed in active and passive sentences.

All the verbs in passive sentences are used in their past participle forms. (in bold)

What is a modal verb?

Click EXAMPLE to read more.

MODALS

·Did you observe that verbs like ‘could, should, may, will’ cannot make sense without the help of another main verb?
·These verbs are often used to express modality such as-

Probabililty - Shirin may not enjoy this movie.

Ability - I can type very fast.

Request - May I come in?
Compulsion - We must prepare the report by tomorrow.

·Such supporting verbs used along with the main verb to attach expressions such as obligation, belief, etc. to your statements are modal auxiliaries or simply auxiliary verbs.

QUICK TIPS

·(Verb+s) form of verb is not used with a modal. For example-
·She goes to her mother’s place.
·She will go to her mother’s place. (correct)
·She will goes to her mother’s place. (incorrect)
·Their negative forms are formed by the simple addition of ‘not’. E.g:
·Sameer will begin the session tomorrow.
·Sameer will not begin the session tomorrow.
·Their forms are never changed for different tenses or number by addition of -s or -ed etc. For example,
·It is wrong to use cans, wills, shoulds to express modality.
·Except for ‘ought to’, they are never followed by ‘to’.
·They differ in meaning and usage when used in different contexts. For example,
·I can lift this heavy sack. (ability)
·Can you help me? (request)

·Vocabulary refers to the sum total of all the words of a language.
·It could also mean the sum total of the words of a language that a person knows and uses.
·A good vocabulary is essential for effective communication and gaining knowledge from literary sources, both oral and written.
·A good vocabulary facilitates reading comprehension.
·A person may know a word, but knowing is not equivalent to recognizing or using it.
·Thus, to build a good vocabulary it is important to be able to recognise and use words correctly in communication.
·Choosing appropriate words to express ourselves is something we all want to do; and this comes along when we build a good vocabulary.
·Sometimes we have some ideas in our mind, but the right word just doesn’t click at the right time, doesn’t that happen with most of us?
·Or you may be jotting your ideas in some words which just don’t suffice, you feel the need for a better substitute.
·That’s where a good vocabulary comes into play. This module will teach you some frequently used words and the activities will help you make your guesses more accurate.

·Make the dictionary your close friend. Make sure to choose a good one such as Oxford’s, Chamber’s and Webster’s. Also ensure your dictionary includes word usage as well because sometimes it’s not enough to know the meaning alone.
·Never put it off till tomorrow. If you come across a new word, make a note of it and head for the dictionary as soon as possible.
·Read a lot. Make sure you read from a quality source- free of grammatical errors and rich in challenging words.
·Look for clues from the surrounding of the word that you don’t know. (The exercises in this module will help you with this)
·Get into the habit of writing. To start with, you could maintain a personal diary. Writing necessitates proper articulation and you will find and learn more and more words in this process.
·Play games. Vocabulary building doesn’t have to be cumbersome at all. Play online vocabulary building games or pair up with your friend to make learning fun.
·Get a thesaurus. A thesaurus is a book that gives you synonyms just as a dictionary is a collection of word meanings. Learning synonymous words is also a good way of boosting your vocabulary.
·Use what you learn. Words are not to be learnt and stored. They only add up to your vocabulary when you use them frequently and correctly in what you write and speak. Have fun with the exercises coming up!

Guess what I mean?

·Deducing meanings of words from the context in which they are used is the easiest way to grasp new words.
·The hints surrounding the word could give you information about its

1. Synonym (words with similar meaning) e.g. : Melancholy- Sad, miserable, Jocular- Funny, playful
2. Antonym (words with opposite meaning) e.g. : Morbid- cheerful, happy
3. Other details citing examples or evidences in support of the word
4. Formation of the word (prefix and suffix) Encapsulated- within a capsule

·Look out for such indications and allow them to guide you to deduce meanings. Let’s take up some examples now.

·Antonymous words in the sentence

Communicate - get your ideas across

·Technically defined, communication is a process of conveying information to someone by written, spoken or non verbal means, the end result of which should ideally be understanding.
·You call the customer care cell of a mobile service provider to seek help for the non functioning of 3G services in your phone. Read the two conversations and decide who addressed your query in a better way.

CASE

Click each CASE to read more.

·If you are able to communicate effectively, be assured that you possess one of the most important life skills.
·Communication is simply the act of information transfer via various means such as vocal (using voice); written (books, magazines, websites); visual (pictures, maps, charts or graphs) or non-verbal (using body language, gestures, the tone and pitch of voice).
·How well this information is transmitted and received tells you how good your communication skills are.
·At workplaces, poor communication skills result in loss of time and resources due to ineffective transmission of messages or mis-communication.
·Developing your communication skills helps you in all aspects of life. The ability to be able to communicate accurately and effectively should not be overlooked. It’s never too late to begin working on your communication skills. This module gives you some promising tips that you must follow to whet your communication abilities.

QUICK TIPS
Perfecting my communication skills

It’s a two way process

·The key to good communication is not just speaking effectively, it is also about being a good listener.
·Before speaking, always be patient enough to allow the speaker to finish.

Do not hurry

·When someone speaks, do not interrupt in between.
·Allow their point to be finished and then speak up.

Follow etiquette

·Always make sure to keep your language free of slang.
·Use professional language; avoid mixing vernacular speech.

Plan beforehand

·Plan well what you are about to put forth. This helps you avoid repetitions which make your listeners less interested in you.
·Also, you wouldn't be missing any important points on your mind.

QUICK TIPS
Honing my communication skills

Am I confident enough?

·Confidence helps you communicate more successfully. It builds trust and relationship.
·You may have all the skills in the world but if you are not confident enough in convincing people about them, they are of no use to you.

Keep it short

·You may be having some spare time to talk a trifle too much, but others may not!
·Convey your message in simple words in the most concise manner.

Do I maintain eye contact?

·Maintaining eye contact is a good sign of effective communication. It helps you connect straight to the listener and gets you the attention you deserve.
·Avoiding eye contact shows your discomfort and you end up getting lesser attention from the listeners.

Make it crystal clear

·After you’ve finished delivering, make it a point to ask people if they need any clarifications from you.
·This helps to avoid chances of misunderstanding which may arise due to lack of clarity in the first place.

Focus on simplicity

·Your aim to communicate is to make yourself clear and understood to the people you are addressing.
·Avoid using confusing statements, double meaning words or very difficult words to impress your audience.
·Getting your idea across should be your prime focus and make it as uncomplicated as possible.

Make the atmosphere light

·Your body language speaks volumes about how good you are at communication.
·Make the process pleasant; avoid use of harsh words.

In written text, what do you do when you want to highlight a point or a single word? You use techniques like bold font, underlining, coloring the text and so on.

It is important to know when and how much to stress particular words relative to the rest of the sentence because in speech, the only means of highlighting a word is to stress its pronunciation.

Thus, depending on what kind of message the speaker wants to convey, the pattern of stress can be chosen by him accordingly.

·“Perhaps”, cried Rohit.
·Perhaps cried Rohit.

One of the basics in a business is learning proper business telephone etiquette. Telephone is an integral part of any business and is usually the first point of contact with clients and customers.

Telephone Etiquette ensures you leave a good impact on your callers.

It indicates your readiness and ability to professionally handle customers. Thus, it is imperative for employees to have a good understanding of telephone etiquette.

Answering a business call at your workplace involves a different approach.

This module introduces you to some of the basics of telephone etiquette along with some model lines which you can practice in your day-to-day telephonic conversations.

Emails that are well composed help you get your ideas across in the most effective way.

Correspondence by email is one of the most preferred forms of business communication because of the convenience with which they can be sent and received.

They simplify a lot of your tasks by offering features like mass communication (using cc option), attachment of numerous documents, maintenance of contact book, etc.

In this module, our emphasis will be on learning to write effective formal mails, which follow a set of rules you will be familiarized with here.

Some sample letters have been provided to make the idea of effective correspondence clear. In addition to this, you need to practice writing some of them yourself in the exercises at the end of the module.

QUICK TIPS - BUSINESS EMAILS - DO's AND DON'Ts

Follow these simple yet essential tips to make your emails incontrovertibly effective.

Being formal

·Understand for whom the mail is being written.
·If the correspondence requires you to be very formal, stick to it.

When not to email

·When you have a long list of things to be discussed and passed on, avoid emailing. Such discussions are better held over phone.
·When urgent information needs to be sent, do not use emails for the purpose.

A proper reply

·Reply to mails in a timely manner. Do not forget to apologise if you fail to do so.
·When the reply needs to be short, avoid using one liners like ‘Ok’ or ‘Thanks’.
·Do not hit the ‘reply all’ button if the message isn’t meant for others to see.
·Make use of ‘bcc’ option to maintain privacy of email ids.

A good beginning

·Salutation is the first thing the recipient notices on opening the mail.
·Avoid addressing the person with his first name.
·When addressing a female, avoid writing Mrs. or Miss, take the safe way and address them as Ms.
·When you do not know the name of the person you are writing to, Dear Sir or Madam will suffice. Another way could be to write the name of the department if it is known, but keep it only as the last option.

Getting to the point

·Stick to your purpose of correspondence.
·Keep your letters short and to the point. Write complete meaningful sentences.
·Keep your mail free of slang and informal greetings.
·The mail should appear neat and not cluttered by jargon, emoticons, etc.
·Compose separate mails to address separate issues.

Sensible Signatures

·Signatures include your name, designation and contact details, website URL and they save you the trouble of typing them every time you write a mail.
·Avoid including unnecessary quotes in your signature.

No errors please

·Check for grammatical errors, wrong spellings and improper punctuation.
·Don’t ever write anything in capitals as it appears very repelling.

The subject

·Sending a mail without a subject line shows rashness on your part and your mails stand a good chance of being ignored.
·A subject also facilitates searching for the right mail when you have multiple mails from a common sender.
·Keep the subject brief and to the point. Some examples include - Application for the post of____, Final reminder for enrolment of_____, Invitation to join X’s network, Request for a revised quote and so on.

Formatting

·Avoid multiple fonts, colored text, graphics and background patterns.
·Use italics and bold only to emphasize certain text. Always use sentence case for composing mails.

Be polite

·Be gentle and polite in writing a mail.
·Use words like please, thank you, could generously.

·When you write an official mail, you would find that some aspects such as complaints, apologies, applications, etc. are frequently encountered. Below given are some suggestions on how to put these into proper words. Note that these may be just tags or phrases and you should use them in appropriate sentences in the correct context.
·Use these phrases and sentences to form letters of your own in the letter writing exercise that follows.

WHY

·Learning to read and understand what we are reading is one of the necessary steps towards literacy. Reading without understanding is like staring at words without knowing what they are about.
·Reading comprehension is the ability to understand what you read.
·Reading comprehension is what allows the reader to interact with the text in a meaningful way.
·It is a direct result of reading fluency. Consider the example-
·Don Kirkpatrick's contribution on evaluation techniques has been the first step towards making training a comprehensive result based process. His contribution on four-levels of evaluation has helped us a lot in accomplishing our project’s objective.

Based on your understanding, answer these questions.

If you weren’t able to answer all of these questions, you probably need to go back to the text and give it a more thorough reading.

Reading without comprehension is not reading.

If you can read and still not interpret what you’ve read, you need to start whetting your comprehension skills.

That’s what our next module’s all about - making you comprehend what you read.

Like any other skill, reading comprehension too can be acquired by practising. Follow the tips given in this module and also practise some passages to make your interpretations more precise.

QUICK TIPS

1. Inculcate reading as a habit

·Read as much as you can from as many sources as possible.
·Reading at bed-time is a must for those who do not find time during their busy work hours.
·Make books your best friends. Get a library membership if possible to have access to quality books.

2. Fluency is a must

·Fluency is the ability to read quickly and accurately with ease.
·It is important from comprehension point of view because those who do read fluently can concentrate better on the comprehension part as they are not disrupted by words.
·If you’re not fluent in reading, you will have to take time to read individual words and split sentences into several bits. In the process, all of your attention gets diverted towards reading properly and there is little room for understanding.
·Get into the habit of reading your text aloud. This will let you understand what portions of the text you are getting stuck at. Highlight those areas and read again with more attention and emphasis.
·Use the chart given here to understand your progress.

3. Speed reading

·Reading reasonably fast helps you when you are required to skim through text at a short notice.
·Do not worry if you can’t read too fast. Speed reading is a good skill to possess, but it isn’t really an absolute requirement. What is more important is fluency, which will automatically make your reading speed well above average.
·Also, there are situations where reading fast is not recommended, for instance, legal documents, important files, text to be proofread, etc. Here, comprehension, regardless of the reading speed is mandatory.
·Thus, keep your speed flexible conforming to the demand of the situation.

4. Take a step at a time

·Practising comprehension passages is a good way of improving comprehension skills.
·Start with simple text where you can answer all related questions effortlessly. Once you are confident to move to the next level, head for it. All this is bound to take some time depending on individual capabilities; do not expect overnight results.
·If you take up challenging texts in the first place, you may end up being disappointed.

5. Frame questions in your mind

·After you have read your passage, pen down all the questions that come to your mind. With every little detail provided in the passage, you could raise a couple of relevant questions.
·Underline difficult words, phrases and idiomatic expressions and try to search their meaning.
·If you are able to answer most of the questions raised, you can be sure that you have understood it all well.

6. Knotty words

·As discussed in the Vocabulary section, new and difficult words are not problematic if you can identify hints and guess their meaning.
·Refer to Vocabulary section for more details and exercises.

7. Visualising and note making

·After having read the extract, form a mental picture of the situation that you just read about.
·In reading comprehension, imagination is a good tool as it helps understand text better. This is because images leave a deeper impact on recalling efficiency as compared to something that is heard or read.
·Put all the pieces of information in the paragraph together to make a complete picture.
·Make subtle notes of the important highlights which are decisive in your comprehension of the text.

8. What’s it all about?

·Every passage revolves around an idea, which is the central theme that it speaks about.
·It may not be expressed in one word or sentence; you will have to understand the whole thing before you can judge what the main idea is. The main theme of the passage is always backed by details to support it.
·Look for examples, facts, opinions, types, supporting ideas, conclusions, comparisons, statistics, etc. which define the tone of the passage.
